thought: The WHOIS information indicates that the domain is privately registered through Domains By Proxy, LLC, which can be a common practice for legitimate privacy reasons but is also used by scam websites to hide their identity. The domain has been registered since 2016, which could lend it some credibility, however, the use of a privacy service makes it difficult to determine the legitimacy based solely on registration data. I should check the website's content more closely and perform a search to see if there are any reports or mentions of it being a scam.

A tech support rep calls and offers to fix a computer bug you haven't even noticed, or a pop-up warning appears on the screen, instructing you to dial a number for help. In ..."}, {'url': 'https://consumer.ftc.gov/consumer-alerts/2024/03/new-tech-support-scammers-want-your-life-savings', 'content': 'Here\'s what to know: Never call a number on a security pop-up warning. Pop-ups that tell you to call tech support are always scams. Never move or transfer your money to "protect it.". Only a scammer will tell you to do that. Never give someone a verification code to log in to your account. Scammers want it to get into your account.'}, {'url': 'https://www.bbb.org/us/ca/yuba-city/profile/information-technology-services/chawla-technical-support-1156-90041981', 'content': 'Chawla Technical Support has 1 locations, ... How to Spot, Avoid and Report Tech Support Scams, "Tech support scammers want you to believe you have a serious problem with your computer, like a ...'}, {'url': 'https://consumer.ftc.gov/articles/how-spot-avoid-and-report-tech-support-scams', 'content': "The scammers are hoping you'll call the phone number to get help. If you're looking for tech support, go to a company you know and trust. Two Things To Know To Avoid a Tech Support Scam. 1. Legitimate tech companies won't contact you by phone, email, or text message to tell you there's a problem with your computer. 2."}, {'url': 'https://consumer.ftc.gov/all-scams/tech-support-scams', 'content': "March 7, 2024. Scammers say and do things that can tell us they're lying — and they're not who they pretend to be. Of course, to hear or see those clues, we have to get past the panic scammers make us feel, thanks to the so-called emergencies they try to create. And since scammers are convincing, that can be hard to do."}]
